item.title: Master of Go Is Walloped by Emotionless Challenger, a Google Computer
item.description: The match between Google DeepMind’s AlphaGo and Lee Se-dol was described as a crucial test of how far research into artificial intelligence has come.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Yonhap News Agency, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Coverage of the Go master Lee Se-dol’s loss to Google DeepMind’s AlphaGo in the first match of the best-of-five series in Seoul, South Korea, on Wednesday.

item.title: Court Orders One of Japan’s Two Operating Nuclear Plants to Shut Down
item.description: It said that the safety measures at the Takahama Nuclear Power Plant, which had been back online for only two months, were insufficient.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:credit: Shojiro Yamauchi/Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Residents cheered a decision by a court in Otsu, Japan, on Wednesday to idle the Takahama Nuclear Power Plant.

item.title: Sinosphere: What Chinese Media Mustn’t Cover at the ‘2 Sessions’
item.description: A list of forbidden news topics reportedly issued by China’s propaganda authorities offers a picture of their anxieties.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The foreign minister of China, Wang Yi, at a news conference on Tuesday on the sidelines of the National People’s Congress in Beijing.

item.title: Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Stage Second Day of Missile Tests
item.description: They said that two rockets, launched from the country’s north, had successfully hit targets over 850 miles away.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A photograph released by a semiofficial news outlet, Fars, that it says shows a test launch of a missile at an undisclosed location in Iran on Wednesday.

item.title: Total Solar Eclipse Sweeps Across Indonesia
item.description: The rare event turned morning into night in some areas and inspired special prayer vigils, cultural dances, live music and observation parties.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: A crowd gathered in Jakarta, Indonesia’s capital, on Wednesday to observe the total solar eclipse, which was visible in nearly half of the country’s 34 provinces.

item.title: After Living Brazil’s Dream, Family Confronts Microcephaly and Economic Crisis
item.description: In the wake of the Zika epidemic, hundreds of families in northeastern Brazil are facing the prospect of raising a disabled child in poverty.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Glecion Amorim, left, with his wife, Ms. Soares, and their infant son, Guilherme.

item.title: Sinosphere: Taiwan and Hainan at Risk of Zika Spread, Scientist Warns
item.description: The two islands both have populations of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which is believed to be the main carrier of the virus.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: An Aedes aegypti mosquito seen through a microscope at the Fiocruz Institute in Recife, Brazil.

item.title: Brazilian Businessman Gets Stiff Sentence in Petrobras Scandal
item.description: Marcelo Odebrecht got more than 19 years in prison after being convicted of corruption and money laundering in the investigation of the state-owned oil company.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA
item.media:description: Marcelo Odebrecht, former chief of a major Brazilian construction company, in July 2015. He was convicted of corruption and money-laundering on Tuesday.

item.title: Harold H. Saunders, Mideast Peace Broker, Dies at 85
item.description: Mr. Saunders helped draft the Camp David peace accords in 1978 and helped negotiate the release of American hostages from the United States embassy in Tehran in 1981.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Former C.E.O. Is Sentenced to 19 Years in Corruption Inquiry
item.description: Marcelo Odebrecht, the former chief executive of Brazil’s largest construction company, was convicted of corruption and money laundering.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA
item.media:description: Marcelo Odebrecht, former chief of a major Brazilian construction company, in July 2015. He was convicted of corruption and money-laundering on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Broadens Sanctions on Joseph Kony and His Group
item.description: The Treasury Department action against Mr. Kony and the Lord’s Resistance Army, an African guerrilla organization, could hamper their ability to raise money by selling poached ivory.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Obama Seeks to Pave Way to Mideast Deal After He Leaves Office
item.description: President Obama is looking past his time in office and weighing a plan that would preserve at least the principle of a two-state solution for his successor to pursue.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel last year.

item.title: Iranian Unit Tests Missiles, Accusing U.S. Of Threats
item.description: Accounts on state television did not specify whether the military had fired any weapons capable of carrying a nuclear warhead, which would violate a U.N. resolution.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: South Korea Accuses North of Hacking Senior Officials’ Phones
item.description: Seoul’s spy agency says that Pyongyang has stolen text messages, contact information and voice conversations, possibly in retaliation for new sanctions.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by North Korea’s official Korean Central News Agency, purportedly showing railway workers in West Pyongyang protesting last week against United Nations Security Council sanctions.

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Authorities Take Over Another Opposition News Source
item.description: The Turkish authorities have seized control of the Cihan news agency, expanding the crackdown against supporters of the Muslim cleric Fethullah Gulen.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Government Raises Its Target for Admitting Political Refugees
item.description: The government said Tuesday that Canada would bring in a total of 55,800 political refugees this year, many of them fleeing the Syrian civil war.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Houthi Rebels Enter Peace Talks With Saudi Arabia
item.description: A delegation from the Houthi rebel movement is conducting peace talks directly with Saudi Arabia for the first time since Yemen’s civil war began nearly a year ago.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA

item.title: W.H.O. Advises Pregnant Women to Avoid Areas Where Zika Is Spreading
item.description: The committee said that they were not recommending that pregnant women avoid whole countries, but that they avoid only “areas” where mosquitoes are transmitting the virus.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Dr. Margaret Chan, the director general of the W.H.O, and Dr. David L. Heymann at a news conference on Tuesday in Geneva after a meeting about the Zika virus.

item.title: American Graduate Student Killed in Stabbing Rampage Near Tel Aviv
item.description: Taylor Force, an Army combat veteran and Vanderbilt graduate student, was killed by a Palestinian man who attacked groups of people in Jaffa.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Eating Leaves, and Other Ways Besieged Syrians Try to Survive
item.description: The report detailed how civilians in 18 areas across the country are forced to scrounge to survive.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
